body: @indented-automation can you try with PS7?  Not able to repro on Windows, macOS, or Linux with PS7 Preview 4
Certainly, I'll do so tomorrow morning :)

works on Windows with 5.1
works on Windows with 7-preview 3
does not work on Linux (Ubuntu) with 6.2.3
does not work on Linux (Ubuntu) with 7-preview 4

Same for me.

This is WSL:
```none
PS /home/chris> uname --all
Linux Titan 4.4.0-18362-Microsoft #1-Microsoft Mon Mar 18 12:02:00 PST 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
And
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.4
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-18362-Microsoft #1-Microsoft Mon Mar 18 12:02:00 PST 2019
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
And many missing ReferencedCommand properties from Get-Alias.

I have a full-fat debian box sitting around as well. I tested this there too.
```none
Linux unifi 4.9.0-6-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.9.82-1+deb9u3 (2018-03-02) x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
Version:
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.4
OS                             Linux 4.9.0-6-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.9.82-1+deb9u3 (2018-03-02)
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
And for completion, some output from Get-Alias on that same Debian box.

Okay, I'm actually swinging around to this not being an issue after all. Sorry!

PowerShell will not resolve the command names from the definition if the module which is the target of the definition is not loaded. Which is perhaps kind of fair really unless you want to trigger the autoloader when Get-Alias is run.

What I didn't try yesterday was loading Windows PS without my profile and my profile ultimately causes Microsoft.PowerShell.Management to load. If I do so, I get exactly the same symptom on Windows PowerShell as PS core variants.

Does this move the problem into the realms of expected behaviour?
@indented-automation yes, that is expected.  I think we can close this.  Thanks!
